segments.en: Linked Discourses 11
3. The Third Chapter
23. The Sambari Sorcery
At Sāvatthī.
The Buddha said this:

segments.pli: “bhūtapubbaṃ, bhikkhave, vepacitti asurindo ābādhiko ahosi dukkhito bāḷhagilāno.
segments.en: “Once upon a time, mendicants, Vepacitti, lord of demons, was sick, suffering, gravely ill.

segments.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo yena vepacitti asurindo tenupasaṅkami gilānapucchako.
segments.en: So Sakka went to see him to ask after his illness.

segments.pli: Addasā kho, bhikkhave, vepacitti asurindo sakkaṃ devānamindaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ.
segments.en: Vepacitti saw Sakka coming off in the distance,
and said to him,
‘Heal me, lord of gods!’
‘Teach me, Vepacitti, the Sambari sorcery.’

segments.pli: ‘Na tāvāhaṃ vācemi, yāvāhaṃ, mārisa, asure paṭipucchāmī’ti.
segments.en: ‘I can’t do that, good sir, until I have consulted with the demons.’

segments.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vepacitti asurindo asure paṭipucchi:
segments.en: Then Vepacitti, lord of demons, asked the demons,
‘Good sirs, may I teach the Sambari sorcery to Sakka, lord of gods?’

segments.pli: ‘Mā kho tvaṃ, mārisa, vācesi sakkaṃ devānamindaṃ sambarimāyan’ti.
segments.en: ‘Do not, good sir, teach the Sambari sorcery to Sakka!’

segments.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vepacitti asurindo sakkaṃ devānamindaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
segments.en: So Vepacitti addressed Sakka in verse:
‘O Maghavā, O Sakka,
king of gods, Sujā’s husband,
a sorceror falls into the terrible hell—
like Sambara, for a hundred years.’”

suttaplex.blurb: When Vepacitti fell ill, Sakka visited his old adversary, who begged to be cured. But Sakka demanded to be taught a powerful magic spell first.
